author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Kent Waldrep, Athlete Whose Injury Led to Advocacy, Dies at 67
description: Partly paralyzed as a college football player, he had a role in the inception of the Americans With Disability Act and raised money for spinal cord research.
content: Kent Waldrep, a former college running back whose paralyzing injury in a 1974 game led to a life of activism in which he served with a federal agency that recommended enactment of the Americans With Disabilities Act and raised millions of dollars for spinal cord research, died on Feb. 27 in Natchitoches, La. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Cities and States Are Easing Covid Rules. Should the Arts Follow?
description: Cultural institutions face tough decisions: Is it safe to drop mask and vaccine requirements, and would doing so be more likely to lure audiences back or keep them away?
content: When music fans walked beneath the familiar piano-shaped awning and into the dark embrace of the Blue Note Jazz Club in Greenwich Village this week, a late-pandemic fixture was missing: No one was checking proof of vaccination and photo IDs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Scotland Apologizes for History of Witchcraft Persecution
description: Nicola Sturgeon, the first minister of Scotland, apologized on behalf of the government for the killing and vilification of thousands of people accused of witchcraft between the 16th and 18th centuries.
content: The persecution began in the 1500s and lasted almost two centuries. Nearly 4,000 people were accused of witchcraft, a vast majority of them women. They were arrested, brutally tortured and coerced into false confessions. Two-thirds of those accused were executed, according to historians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Pressing for Evidence, Jan. 6 Panel Argues That Trump Committed Fraud
description: The argument was a response to a lawsuit filed by John Eastman, who is seeking to shield his communications with former President Donald J. Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol on Tuesday laid out its theory for potential criminal charges against former President Donald J. Trump, arguing before a federal judge that he and the conservative lawyer John C. Eastman were involved in a conspiracy to perpetrate a fraud on the American public as part of a plan to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Russia’s Other Contest With the West: Economic Endurance
description: Which side can maintain domestic support as the war costs regular citizens could also determine the outcome in Ukraine.
content: As Russia’s invasion of Ukraine grinds on, Moscow is finding itself mired in a parallel conflict: a contest of economic and political endurance against the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Mark Meadows Spread Trump’s Voter Fraud Claims. Now His Voting Record Is Under Scrutiny.
description: The former Trump aide listed a mobile home in rural North Carolina as his residence at the same time that he was running operations at the White House.
content: Mark Meadows, the White House chief of staff who helped former President Donald J. Trump spread false claims of voter fraud in an attempt to overturn the results of the 2020 election, is facing questions about his own voting record, following a report that he registered to vote from a North Carolina mobile home where he did not live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Mexican Women Protest Femicides as President Warns Against Violence
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has been accused of not doing enough to stem the rise in violence against women.
content: MEXICO CITY — An International Women’s Day rally in Mexico on Tuesday drew thousands of protesters, with throngs marching against violence and streaming past the presidential palace and national monuments in the capital that had been cordoned off with huge metal fences amid fears of unrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: canny
description: This word has appeared in 108 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word canny has appeared in 108 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 20 in “At Billie Eilish’s Arena Show, the Only Spectacle Is Herself” by Lindsay Zoladz:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chantel Tattoli
title: Are You an Astier Person?
description: Over two decades, Astier de Villatte’s ceramics have quietly come to define a certain kind of taste.
content: On a trip to New York about a decade ago, Benoît Astier de Villatte and Ivan Pericoli stopped at ABC Carpet & Home in Manhattan. The store was among the first to stock ceramics from Astier de Villatte, the line the men co-founded in Paris in 1996. They were admiring how some of their dishes were displayed when a salesclerk told them the pieces were copies of those used by Marie Antoinette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Twitter Bot Highlights Gender Pay Gap One Company at a Time
description: Britain requires companies with 250 or more employees to report gender pay gap data. On International Women’s Day, one couple used it to raise awareness about lingering discrepancies.
content: Each International Women’s Day, photos of smiling women appear in a steady stream on social media alongside testimonials from brands eager to show their support for gender equality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Is Your Relationship Like With Your Grandparents and Elders?
description: What memories come to mind when you think of them?
content: Have you had close relationships with grandparents or other elders during your life? What memories come to mind when you think of them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Austria Does a U-Turn on Mandatory Vaccinations, Citing Milder Variant Cases
description: Despite high caseloads, the number of Covid patients in intensive-care-unit beds remains steady, prompting the country to rethink its approach, at least for now.
content: BERLIN — Four months ago, Austria made headlines when it announced plans to become the first Western democracy to impose a general vaccine mandate to fight the coronavirus, a measure that would have hit adults who refused to be inoculated with fines of up to 3,600 euros (about $4,000).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Fred Ferretti, Reporter Turned Writer on Food, Dies at 90
description: He covered every aspect of dining for The Times from 1969 to 1986 and then became a columnist for Gourmet magazine.
content: Fred Ferretti, who covered a panoply of breaking news events for New York City newspapers before becoming best known for his prolific writing on cuisine, comestibles and cooking for The New York Times and then Gourmet magazine, died on Monday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. Cancels Another Week of Games as Lockout Continues
description: The league and the players negotiated long after another self-imposed deadline, but a deal was not reached to save a 162-game season.
content: Despite a marathon negotiating session that dragged from Tuesday morning until Wednesday night — with only a brief respite for sleep — Major League Baseball and the players’ union could not resolve a roadblock and reach a new labor deal ahead of a 6 p.m. deadline set by the league.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks Workers at 3 More Buffalo-Area Stores Vote to Unionize
description: The ballots were counted amid a growing nationwide campaign among the chain’s employees.
content: Employees at three more Buffalo-area Starbucks have voted to unionize, bringing the total number of company-owned stores with a union to six, out of roughly 9,000 nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: With ‘The Godfather,’ Art Imitated Mafia Life. And Vice Versa.
description: Federal wiretaps and Mob insiders suggest that many real-life wiseguys turned to the 1972 film for inspiration, validation and cues on how to speak and act and dress.
content: A table for five at CaSa Bella in Little Italy in the late 1970s included a few mobsters, a girlfriend and the man they knew as Donnie Brasco, actually an undercover F.B.I. agent. There was business to discuss, but then the mood lightened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Who Will Win This Year’s Wild Best Actress Race?
description: There are cases to be made for and against every contender, and no one has an obvious advantage in this upended season.
content: The best actress category is doing the most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Charles E. Entenmann, Last of a Storied Baking Family, Dies at 92
description: Working with his brothers and their mother, he helped turn the company that bore their name into a nationally known symbol of sweetness.
content: Charles E. Entenmann, the last of three brothers who, with their mother, ran a Long Island bakery as it became one of the nation’s best-known producers of baked-goods, died on Feb. 24 in Hialeah, Fla. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: I’ll Say It Again: There’s More Than One Way to Raise Kids Who Thrive
description: Packaged methods can’t prevent the frustrations of parenting.
content: The parenting method RIE — that stands for Resources for Infant Educarers and is pronounced “rye” — and its most famous practitioner, Janet Lansbury, are having another high-profile moment, with interviews this year by Ezra Klein in The Times and Ariel Levy in The New Yorker. And because I’m old and cranky and have been on the parenting beat for a minute, my gut response to this resurgence is: Again? I remember RIE’s previous moments in the sun, with features in Vanity Fair in 2014 and The Daily Beast in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Radio Drama for a Podcast Age: How Amazon’s Audible Moved Into Theater
description: A company known for audiobooks is mounting starry live productions — and recording them, too.
content: Elizabeth Marvel took off her shoes, stretched out her arms and started describing her horrible dreams. Ato Blankson-Wood offered thoughts on astrology. Bill Camp, cradling a guitar in his lap, asked if someone could go get coffee, while Jason Bowen adjusted his chair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Peat, Coin Collecting, Civil Rights
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about the environmental benefits of peat, share the things they love to collect, watch a film about the 10th anniversary of Trayvon Martin’s death, talk about their experiences doing D.I.Y. projects, and make observations about a photograph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: With Humor, and a Nod to History, Johnson and Zelensky Find a Rapport
description: Forging an alliance with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was a natural for Boris Johnson, Britain’s prime minister. The two share a sense of the moment.
content: LONDON — When President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine thanked British lawmakers for their solidarity in an emotional video address to the House of Commons on Tuesday evening, he singled out a particular member watching him raptly from the frontbench: Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A man who bought a Pokémon card for $57,000 with Covid relief money is sentenced to prison.
description: The forfeitures have included Lamborghinis, gold bars and luxury goods from Dior.
content: The forfeitures have included Lamborghinis, gold bars and luxury goods from Dior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘Woman’ Is an Ambitious Attempt to Capture Four Centuries of Being Female
description: Lillian Faderman’s exhaustive survey of American history comes up to the present but stops short of engaging with today’s charged gender debates.
content: We’ve come a long way, baby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: After a Week of Siege, Bloodied Mariupol Plans Mass Graves
description: Under a relentless Russian barrage, there is no heat or electricity, and people are boiling snow for water. A 6-year-old died of dehydration, the authorities said.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Marina Levinchuk said she received an alarming text message from the local authorities in the besieged city of Mariupol several days ago, before she decided to flee. “If somebody dies in your family,” she said, recalling the message in her own words, “just put the body outside, cover it, tie up the hands and the legs and leave it outside.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Ephrat Livni
title: Biden Takes Step Toward Regulating Cryptocurrencies
description: The president signed an executive order that will coordinate efforts among financial regulators to better understand the risks and opportunities presented by digital assets.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden signed an executive order on Wednesday directing the federal government to come up with a plan to regulate cryptocurrencies, recognizing their popularity and potential to destabilize traditional finance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla and Erin Woo
title: Why California Gas Prices Are Especially High
description: At more than $5 per gallon, gasoline is more expensive here than anywhere else in the nation.
content: The price of gasoline in the United States reached a new high on Tuesday at $4.173 per gallon, surpassing the previous high set in July 2008.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Michael Levenson
title: ‘Black Panther’ Director Ryan Coogler Mistaken for Bank Robber in Atlanta
description: “We deeply regret that this incident occurred,” Bank of America said in a statement about the episode on Jan. 7. “It never should have happened, and we have apologized to Mr. Coogler.”
content: Bank of America has apologized to the director Ryan Coogler after he was assumed to be a bank robber and briefly handcuffed by the police while trying to withdraw money from a branch in Atlanta in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Al Pacino on ‘The Godfather’: ‘It’s Taken Me a Lifetime to Accept It and Move On’
description: Fifty years later, the actor looks back on his breakthrough role: how he was cast, why he skipped the Oscars and what it all means to him now.
content: It’s hard to imagine “The Godfather” without Al Pacino. His understated performance as Michael Corleone, who became a respectable war hero despite his corrupt family, goes almost unnoticed for the first hour of the film — until at last he asserts himself, gradually taking control of the Corleone criminal operation and the film along with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainara Tiefenthäler, Evan Hill, Dmitriy Khavin, Masha Froliak and Haley Willis
title: Videos show devastating strike at Mariupol hospital maternity ward.
description: Footage from the hospital verified by The New York Times showed several wounded people being evacuated. The extent of the casualties was not immediately clear.
content: An apparent Russian strike on Wednesday damaged and destroyed buildings at a hospital complex in the southern Ukrainian city of Mariupol, including a maternity ward, according to several videos verified by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Cuomo? Oh No!
description: Things could always be worse on the governor front.
content: So, people, how would you feel about an Andrew Cuomo comeback?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: ‘Australia Is Getting Harder to Live In’: Unending Rain, Growing Floods
description: At least 20 people have died and tens of thousands have been ordered to evacuate as record rainfall continues to inundate the country’s eastern coast.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Australia’s prime minister declared a national emergency on Wednesday as more than a week of severe rain along the country’s eastern coast has caused some of the worst flooding in Australian history and inundated swaths of two of its largest cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Meta’s head of youth product initiatives departs the company.
description: The most prominent effort was a version of Instagram for children.
content: The vice president who led youth product initiatives at Meta, Facebook’s parent company, is leaving after an internal restructuring, according to a company memo on Wednesday that was obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, Kenneth P. Vogel, Jesse Drucker, Maureen Farrell and Mike McIntire
title: How Western Firms Quietly Enabled Russian Oligarchs
description: Investment, law and lobbying firms have helped enmesh Kremlin-linked oligarchs into the Western financial and legal systems.
content: Behind a set of imposing metal doors in an easy-to-miss office building in a New York City suburb, a small team manages billions of dollars for a Russian oligarch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Chernobyl Loses Power
description: Also, Poland’s fighter jet offer goes awry.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Zverev’s Swings Merited More Than a Slap on the Wrist
description: After striking the umpire’s chair during an outburst at a tournament in Mexico, Alexander Zverev can avoid a fine and suspension if he does not commit further violations for one year.
content: SAN DIEGO — Somehow, the men’s tennis tour is allowing the German star Alexander Zverev to play on. He will be in the field for the BNP Paribas Open, which begins this week in Indian Wells, Calif., despite his frightening, unacceptable abuse of an official just two weeks ago after a defeat in doubles in Acapulco, Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Spy Agencies Cite Russia’s Setbacks but Say Putin Is ‘Unlikely to Be Deterred’
description: Top U.S. intelligence officials told Congress that the Russian leader had underestimated Ukrainian resolve and Western cohesion but was “doubling down” to achieve his goals.
content: WASHINGTON — Top U.S. intelligence officials said on Tuesday that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had been surprised and unsettled by the problems that have hampered his military in Ukraine, issues that will make it more difficult for Russian forces to control the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: New Rules for a New World
description: Ukraine’s brave stand should be an opportunity to rethink the way in which we look at foreign affairs for the next decade.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is being described as the end of the post-Cold War era. This isn’t quite accurate. Since the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, we’ve seen three different eras. Each of them lasted about a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Do Covid Precautions Work?
description: Yes, but they haven’t made a big difference.
content: Daily life in red and blue America has continued to be quite different over the past few months. It’s a reflection of the partisan divide over Covid-19. Consider:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: Beyond Girlfriend-Boyfriend
description: For one Black woman, embracing polyamory has allowed her to “experience the expansiveness of love.”
content: Three months into the coronavirus pandemic, Haili Blassingame was crafting an email to her boyfriend of five years, Malcolm, with the subject line “My Terms.” She wanted to break up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Alan Feuer and Adam Bednar
title: After Ottawa, Trucker Convoy Near Washington Is a Low-Key Protest
description: As the caravan of semis, pickups and R.V.s circled the U.S. capital, downtown D.C. was business as usual.
content: HAGERSTOWN, Md. — When a convoy of trucks pulled out of Southern California last month, rolling toward the U.S. capital just days after the police in Canada cracked down on a legion of truckers occupying Ottawa, Washington braced for their arrival. The Department of Homeland Security issued a warning, and members of the National Guard were deployed, along with hundreds of city police officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Russia’s ruble continues its slide as new curbs restrict access to foreign currency.
description: As the currency loses purchasing power, Russia’s central bank is trying to support the ruble with expanded rules preventing exchanges into dollars.
content: Russia's currency continued its descent on Wednesday as trading in the ruble was restarted on the Moscow Exchange. But in an effort to stanch the currency’s decline, the Russian central bank issued an order further restricting access to U.S. dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Yoon Suk-yeol, South Korean Conservative Leader, Wins Presidency
description: As a prosecutor, he went after former presidents. Now voter discontent has helped him take the presidency in the tightest race since 1987.
content: SEOUL — A graft prosecutor turned opposition leader has won an extremely close presidential election in South Korea, reinstating conservatives to power with calls for a more confrontational stance against North Korea and a stronger alliance with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Restores California’s Power to Set Stringent Tailpipe Rules
description: The state is expected to write strict auto pollution standards designed to significantly speed the transition to electric vehicles and influence new federal rules.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Wednesday restored California’s legal authority to set auto pollution and mileage rules that are tighter than federal standards, a potent climate policy that had been stripped away by former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Leslie Jones Gets Revved Up by Vinyl, Live Tweeting and ‘Euphoria’
description: Sometimes even Leslie Jones doesn’t want to be Leslie Jones. That’s why her new comedy series, “Our Flag Means Death,” checks all of the boxes.
content: “I was in as soon as they said, ‘Black pirate,’” Leslie Jones recalled about the offer to play Spanish Jackie in the HBO Max series “Our Flag Means Death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘The Godfather’ Explained in Seven Quotes
description: The film’s lines have become part of our collective memory. Seven writers, directors and actors look back at the movie and what these words mean to them.
content: When Francis Ford Coppola’s “The Godfather” opened in New York on March 15, 1972, critics immediately understood the mob family drama to be a masterpiece. But they could not have foreseen how some of the dialogue would become part of our collective memory, often turning into catchphrases divorced from the film itself. In honor of the 50th anniversary of “The Godfather,” we asked seven fans — critics, actors, directors — to look back at Don Vito Corleone, sons Sonny and Michael, and henchmen like Clemenza and Tom Hagen, to reflect on key lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: There Are Glimmers of Hope for Biden. Or Maybe Slivers.
description: “Biden is finally getting some good news after a long period of horrible events,” says one Republican strategist.
content: Despite the terrible reality of the war in Ukraine, rising inflation and record gas prices, a faint ray of sunshine has fallen on Joe Biden and the Democratic Party. According to strategists for both parties, the Democrats now have a 50-50 chance of retaining control of the Senate in the midterm elections, crucial for the appointment of federal judges, but nowhere near enough electoral strength to give them a shot at keeping their House majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: They Predicted the Ukraine War. But Did They Still Get It Wrong?
description: What Putin’s invasion has revealed about realism and idealism in foreign policy.
content: It’s a curious feature of Western debate since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine that a school of thought that predicted some version of this conflict has been depicted as discredited by the partial fulfillment of its prophecies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Luke Vander Ploeg, Diana Nguyen, John Ketchum, Paige Cowett, Larissa Anderson, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Will Banning Russian Oil Hurt Russia, or the U.S.?
description: It is the United States’ most dramatic step yet to punish President Vladimir V. Putin for waging war on Ukraine.
content: On Tuesday morning, President Biden took to the podium at the White House to deliver a solemn and provocative speech. As punishment for waging war on Ukraine, he announced, the United States would cut off Russian oil imports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Tying and Re-Tying the Knot
description: Couples recount the experience of having two or three wedding events because of the pandemic, a trend some experts say will continue to influence how many celebrate.
content: Read more about the 2022 wedding boom in our ongoing Year of the Wedding series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Long Covid Exhausts the Body’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the long-lasting symptoms that some people experience after a coronavirus infection. Then, they will conduct additional research and educate others about long Covid.
content: Featured Article: “How Long Covid Exhausts the Body” by Josh Keller
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Gregor
title: House Hunting in the Virgin Islands: Hillside Splendor for Under $2 Million
description: After enduring back-to-back crises in recent years, the British Virgin Islands are beginning to see the return of tourists and foreign investors.
content: This four-bedroom villa with Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea views sits on a hillside on the northwest coast of Tortola, in the British Virgin Islands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Kasulis Cho
title: Lee Jae-myung is a technocrat with hardscrabble origins.
description: His challenge is to promise continuity with the ruling party’s policies, yet distinguish himself from the current president.
content: South Korea’s leading liberal candidate, Lee Jae-myung, started his presidential bid with a speech that spoke squarely to the country’s simmering angst and its struggling middle class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Geffen Hall’s $550 Million Makeover Is Fully Funded
description: The New York Philharmonic’s home will reopen in October, a year and a half ahead of schedule, after construction was accelerated during the pandemic.
content: Gone are the mustard-colored seats and shoe box interior of David Geffen Hall, the New York Philharmonic’s home at Lincoln Center. When the hall reopens this fall, wavy beech wood will wrap around the stage — and so will the audience, in seats upholstered in richly colored patterns evoking flower petals in motion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Bans Oil Imports From Russia, Calling It a ‘Blow to Putin’s War Machine’
description: Officials said President Biden had struggled for days over the move amid deep concerns about accelerating the already rapid rise in the price of gasoline.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Tuesday banned imports of Russian oil, gas and coal in response to what he called President Vladimir V. Putin’s “vicious war of choice” in Ukraine, but warned Americans that the decision to inflict economic pain on Russia would inevitably mean higher gas prices at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Most Size-Inclusive Brand at Fashion Week
description: The young label Ester Manas broke from the crowd in Paris with a truly diverse cast of models.
content: There’s a lot to see at fashion week. Blink (or scroll too fast) and you’ll miss the details: feathered bags, futuristic sunglasses, fork jewelry. All month long, we’ll spotlight the things we saw that surprised or delighted us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Western moves to isolate Russia.
content: President Biden banned imports of Russian oil, gas and coal to the U.S. in response to what he called a “vicious war of choice” in Ukraine by Vladimir Putin, the Russian leader. Biden warned Americans that the decision to inflict economic pain on Russia would inevitably mean higher gas prices at home. “Defending freedom is going to cost,” he said in televised remarks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Vanessa Friedman
title: No Ikea Shelves, No Levis: The Retail Exodus From Russia Is On
description: Since the invasion of Ukraine began, the increasing financial and reputational risks of doing business in Russia are leading Western brands to halt operations.
content: On Monday, the chief financial officer of Stanley Black & Decker told investors that the company was still figuring out whether it was going to keep its business in Russia given new sanctions affecting the country, or exit in coming weeks or months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: A Lion of the Civil Rights Era Is Still Preaching Optimism
description: Andrew Young, the former mayor of Atlanta and a friend of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., is being honored at a time of racial tensions at home and violent invasion abroad.
content: ATLANTA — Andrew Young was beaten by white supremacists at a civil rights march in St. Augustine, Fla., in 1964. And he was close by when an assassin’s bullet fatally severed the spine of his friend and mentor, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., in Memphis in 1968.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Evgeny Maslin, Russian General Who Secured Nuclear Arsenal, Dies at 84
description: He persuaded Ukraine and other post-Soviet states to give up their weapons, then worked with the U.S. to safeguard and dismantle thousands of them.
content: Evgeny Maslin, a Russian general who, after the fall of the Soviet Union, set Cold War-era enmities aside to work with the United States in securing his country’s nuclear arsenal, a process that included the withdrawal of thousands of warheads from Ukraine, died on Feb. 26 at a hospital in Moscow. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Patient in Groundbreaking Heart Transplant Dies
description: David Bennett Sr. had received a heart from a genetically modified pig, a procedure that may yet offer hope to millions of Americans needing transplants.
content: The first person to have his failing heart replaced with that of a genetically altered pig in a groundbreaking operation died Tuesday afternoon at the University of Maryland Medical Center, two months after the transplant surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: Most of the world’s new known virus cases this year emerged in the Americas, W.H.O. officials say.
description: Countries in the region should keep public health measures in place, W.H.O. officials warned.
content: The Americas continue to be disproportionately affected by the coronavirus pandemic, and it is too soon for countries in the region to relax public health measures, World Health Organization officials warned on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: At the Bottom of an Icy Sea, One of History’s Great Wrecks Is Found
description: Explorers and researchers, battling freezing temperatures, have located Endurance, Ernest Shackleton’s ship that sank in the Antarctic in 1915.
content: The wreck of Endurance has been found in the Antarctic, 106 years after the historic ship was crushed in pack ice and sank during an expedition by the explorer Ernest Shackleton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: The Vaccine Mandate Remains at Some New York City Restaurants
description: Though the city dropped its rule, several restaurants are asking indoor diners for proof of vaccination. One of them drew protesters.
content: On Tuesday night, about 20 people descended on Dame, in Greenwich Village, to protest the restaurant’s request that indoor diners provide proof of vaccination, a day after the city dropped its vaccine mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Putin’s Getting Sanctioned, but Russia’s Getting Canceled
description: Russian people, businesses and products with  little or no relationship to the invasion have found themselves in the culture war’s crosshairs.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Pandemic Has Pulled Reading Skills Down Into ‘New Territory’
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 9, 2022.
content: “That feeling of guilt comes over me. What about the kids in the Bronx?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Patrick Kingsley and Michael Crowley
title: Subtle Shifts Raise Hopes for a Cease-fire in Ukraine
description: Both Russia and Ukraine appear to have softened their stance, with the Kremlin signaling a retreat on regime change and Kyiv expressing flexibility on NATO membership. But the two sides remain far apart.
content: ISTANBUL — When President Vladimir V. Putin launched his invasion two weeks ago, he said a primary goal was the “denazification” of Ukraine. He referred to the Ukrainian government as a “gang of drug addicts and neo-Nazis,” making it clear that his aim was to topple it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Biden Nominates Roselyn Tso, of the Navajo Nation, to Run Indian Health Service
description: The president had made a campaign promise to address the longstanding issues plaguing the agency, which has lacked consistent leadership.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said Wednesday he would nominate Roselyn Tso to serve as director of the Indian Health Service, raising hopes of a fresh start for an agency that has drawn intense criticism over the years for failing to provide adequate care to tribal communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: The Virtuoso Sara Mearns Considers Other Virtuosities
description: In “Piece of Work” at the Joyce, Mearns dives into collaborations with choreographers outside the ballet world, including Jodi Melnick and Beth Gill.
content: Sara Mearns is a go-for-broke dancer. As a star of New York City Ballet, she dances on a thrillingly huge scale, combining the drama of risk and abandon with the drama of glamour and emotion. But she has realized that there are other kinds of virtuosity, and in recent years she has been exploring them with the same headlong energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: A Brick on an Egg
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Colorado County Clerk Indicted in Voting Security Breach Investigation
description: The Mesa County clerk, Tina Peters, is charged with 10 counts related to tampering with voting equipment. A Republican running for secretary of state, she has promoted false claims of fraud in the 2020 election.
content: Tina Peters, a county clerk running as a Republican for secretary of state of Colorado, was indicted Tuesday evening on 10 criminal counts related to allegations that she tampered with election equipment after the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Nadja Popovich
title: How Air Pollution Across America Reflects Racist Policy From the 1930s
description: A new study shows how redlining, a Depression-era housing policy, contributed to inequalities that persist decades later in U.S. cities.
content: Urban neighborhoods that were redlined by federal officials in the 1930s tended to have higher levels of harmful air pollution eight decades later, a new study has found, adding to a body of evidence that reveals how racist policies in the past have contributed to inequalities across the United States today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Employers are still scrambling to fill vacancies, a new U.S. report shows.
description: Openings remained high in January, the Labor Department reported, as did the number of workers quitting their jobs.
content: Job openings in the United States and the number of workers quitting their jobs remained near record highs in January, an indicator of demand for labor and of worker leverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: From the Left, a Historian’s Plea for Democratic Party Unity
description: Michael Kazin’s new book offers a pointed warning to his fellow progressives, and a surprising defense of President Biden.
content: The Democratic Party is going through one of its periodic convulsions, with an insurgent left battling for pre-eminence over a centrist establishment led by President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Republicans Wrongly Blame Biden for Rising Gas Prices
description: They have pointed to the Biden administration’s policies on the Keystone XL pipeline and certain oil and gas leases, which have had little impact on prices.
content: WASHINGTON — As gas prices hit a high this week, top Republican lawmakers took to the airwaves and the floors of Congress with misleading claims that pinned the blame on President Biden and his energy policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Woman Hid Moscow Ties While Pushing ‘I Love Russia’ Propaganda, U.S. Says
description: Elena Branson was charged with violating federal laws requiring agents of foreign governments to disclose their official ties.
content: A woman who led an “I Love Russia” propaganda campaign in the United States as a citizen of both countries was charged on Tuesday with flouting federal law by failing to register as an agent of a foreign government, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Cluster Munitions and ‘Vacuum Bombs’: Russian Invasion Revives an Old Debate
description: Diplomats and talking heads have repeated longstanding fictions about battlefield weapons that critics argue are too cruel or too indiscriminate for use in warfare.
content: During an emergency meeting of the United Nations General Assembly last Wednesday, called in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the U.S. ambassador made an allegation about the weapons being used in the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Alain Graillot, Influential Rhône Valley Winemaker, Dies at 77
description: Skilled, charismatic and energetic, he found success in a region that had not been esteemed for its wines, helping to raise its international reputation.
content: Alain Graillot, who had never made a drop of wine when he arrived in the Crozes-Hermitage region of the Northern Rhône Valley in France in 1985 but became one of its leading producers, raising the reputation of its wines internationally, died on Friday at a hospital in Grenoble. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Where Fashion Stylists Shop for Vintage
description: Desert Vintage came from Tucson to the Lower East Side. It’s already right at home.
content: One afternoon in late February, the owners of the new Lower East Side vintage boutique Desert Vintage were musing about their customers. “Our clientele will wear Philo-era Celine trousers with an Edwardian top,” said Salima Boufelfel, who owns the shop with her partner, Roberto Cowan. “It’s never just ’90s Prada or a turn-of-the-century lace collar. It’s the mix of these different elements that tell a larger story. It’s a mash-up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: New York’s First Supertall Tower Outside Manhattan Rises in Brooklyn
description: The 1,066-foot Brooklyn Tower is starting sales as the luxury market once again booms, but concerns about supertall tower construction are still fresh in buyers’ minds.
content: Near the top of the 1,066-foot Brooklyn Tower in Downtown Brooklyn, wind whipped across the unfinished concrete slab, and the developer, Michael Stern, showcased the stunning, sky-high views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden offers more free coronavirus tests although demand has slowed.
description: The Biden administration on Tuesday formally began allowing Americans who had ordered free coronavirus tests this winter to request a second round of four tests per household, through the same U.S. Postal Service program that President Biden unveiled in January.
content: The Biden administration on Tuesday formally began allowing Americans who had ordered free coronavirus tests this winter to request a second round of four tests per household, through the same U.S. Postal Service program that President Biden unveiled in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Sharks Sleep, Even When Both Eyes Are Wide Open
description: While sharks have a reputation for always being on the move, some of them really do catch some rest.
content: Sharks are celebrated for their apparently ceaseless motion — a small handful of species such as great white sharks must even swim to breathe, keeping water washing over their gills. Still, all that moving doesn’t preclude sharks from having a rest. Sleep across the animal kingdom manifests itself in many peculiar ways, like the birds whose brains sleep one half at a time or the bats that spend almost every hour of their day snoozing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Tony Awards to Announce Prizes in June at Radio City Music Hall
description: The 75th ceremony, honoring plays and musicals staged on Broadway, resumes its traditional calendar after a few years of pandemic disruption.
content: This year’s Tony Awards will take place on June 12 at Radio City Music Hall as the theater industry seeks to settle in to some sort of new normal following the enormous disruption of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Californians may get tax rebate to combat soaring fuel prices.
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom addressed the cost of gas, which is the highest in the nation, during his State of the State address.
content: As political leaders across the country scramble to address soaring gas prices, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced on Tuesday that he would seek to give residents relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Marc Santora
title: Quoting Churchill and Shakespeare, Ukraine Leader Vows No Surrender
description: In a dramatic video address to Britain’s House of Commons, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said he would never capitulate to the invading Russians.
content: LONDON — With Ukraine’s outgunned army holding firm despite Russian bombardments that have displaced millions of civilians, the war in Ukraine has become a grim spectacle of resistance, no one more defiant than the country’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, who vowed on Tuesday never to give in to Russia’s tanks, troops or artillery shells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Richard Sherman Pleads Guilty to Charges From Family Altercation
description: The N.F.L. cornerback, who pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges of negligent driving and criminal trespass, was fined but avoided jail time after being credited for time served.
content: The free-agent N.F.L. cornerback Richard Sherman pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors on Monday, resolving charges from last summer when he was arrested after police said he drunkenly crashed his car and tried to break down the door of his in-laws’ home in Redmond, Wash., a suburb outside of Seattle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Volodymyr Zelensky Is Playing the Role of His Life
description: In his TV sitcom and now at war, Ukraine’s actor-president has modeled an idea of leadership that is very different from Vladimir Putin’s.
content: Shortly after his surprise election as the president of Ukraine, Vasyl Petrovych Holoborodko gets a Pygmalion-like makeover and an introduction to his retinue of staff. There is his stylist. There is his psychologist. There is his “personal motivator.” And there is … himself?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Yoon Suk-yeol helped prosecute presidents. Now he wants to be one.
description: Mr. Yoon, the leading conservative candidate, hopes to win the election by appealing to South Koreans who are deeply dissatisfied with the outgoing administration.
content: As a star prosecutor, Yoon Suk-yeol, the leading conservative candidate, helped imprison two former presidents as well as the head of Samsung and a former chief justice of the country’s Supreme Court on charges of corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld and Erin Woo
title: Elizabeth Holmes’s Ex-Boyfriend Hopes to Escape the Verdict She Didn’t
description: Jury selection started in Sunny Balwani’s fraud trial, which will establish just how much he knew about the blood-testing start-up Theranos and Ms. Holmes’s actions.
content: Elizabeth Holmes was a star entrepreneur whose trial for defrauding investors in her blood-testing start-up became one of the biggest Silicon Valley spectacles since the introduction of the iPhone. Her conviction in January marked a rare moment in the boastful history of technology: A chief executive was held criminally responsible for lying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: An Artist and Met Museum Guard Whose New Work Is About Pay: Her Own
description: Emilie Lemakis’s project of making buttons that show the wages and years of service of museum guards has taken on an extra resonance as their union pushes for a raise.
content: For decades Emilie Lemakis has made art rooted in the experiences and ephemera of her daily life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Mona El-Naggar and Michael Forsythe
title: How a Playground for the Rich Could Undermine Sanctions on Oligarchs
description: Allies of President Vladimir Putin, arriving on private jets and yachts, are still welcome in the U.A.E., which has yet to condemn the Ukraine invasion or enforce sanctions.
content: Stretching into the Persian Gulf from the beaches and skyscrapers of Dubai is a man-made archipelago in the shape of a vast palm tree, its branchlike rows of islands lined with luxury hotels, apartments and villas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Before Jussie Smollett Sentencing, His Supporters Ask for ‘Mercy’
description: A judge must decide whether to send the actor to prison after a jury convicted him last year of falsely reporting that he was the victim of a racist and homophobic hate crime in 2019.
content: Ahead of a sentencing hearing on Thursday, celebrities and racial justice advocates like Samuel L. Jackson and his wife, the actress LaTanya Richardson Jackson; the Rev. Jesse Jackson; and Derrick Johnson, the president of the N.A.A.C.P., have written letters pleading for leniency for Jussie Smollett, the actor convicted of falsely reporting that he was the victim of a racist and homophobic attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Henry Fountain
title: Damaged Chernobyl Nuclear Plant, Occupied by Russia, Loses Outside Power
description: The site of the worst nuclear accident in history, where a yearslong cleanup is underway, is now dependent on power from diesel generators and backup supplies.
content: Ukrainian government officials said Wednesday that damage by Russian forces had left the defunct Chernobyl nuclear power plant “disconnected” from outside electricity, leaving the site of the worst nuclear accident in history dependent on power from diesel generators and backup supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Safak Timur
title: Israel’s President Visits Turkey in Sign of Thawing Relations
description: In their highest-level meeting in 14 years, Israel and Turkey sought to rekindle an alliance after years of turbulence.
content: JERUSALEM — President Isaac Herzog of Israel was received on Wednesday with pomp and ceremony by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey during a state visit described by both sides as an effort to reset after years of testy and broken relations between the onetime regional allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Russia Bombards Ukraine Cities and Accuses U.S. of ‘Economic War’
description: Misery deepened in Ukraine, where millions of people were caught in besieged cities, and in Russia, where the West’s economic sanctions were biting hard.
content: Russian forces bombarded Ukrainian cities, prevented hundreds of thousands of civilians from escaping and destroyed a maternity hospital on Wednesday, while the Kremlin accused the United States of waging “an economic war” against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Ukraine’s first lady emerges into the spotlight to condemn Russia’s invasion and plead for help.
description: Olena Zelenska says in a letter that Russian forces are engaged in the “mass murder of civilians” and reiterates her husband’s call for a no-fly zone.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — As her husband has become a global symbol of leadership in the face of Russia’s invasion, Ukraine’s first lady, Olena Zelenska, has taken on a less public role. But on Tuesday evening, she emerged into the media spotlight, sending an open letter that she said was her “testimony” from Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Often in Italian
description: Peter Gordon punctuates his puzzle.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — This is Peter Gordon’s 124th New York Times Crossword puzzle, and it’s a silly one! Wordplay that involves wacky phrases and clues is one of my favorite theme types, and this puzzle definitely checks that box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney C.E.O. Says Company Is ‘Opposed’ to Florida’s ‘Don’t Say Gay’ Bill
description: Bob Chapek’s remarks followed criticism that the company, a major employer in the state because of Disney World, had not spoken out against the legislation.
content: It was a bruised Bob Chapek who arrived at Disney’s annual shareholder meeting on Wednesday — and all because of a crisis of his own making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Djokovic says he won’t attend U.S. tournaments over vaccination status.
description: The player was unable to defend his Australian Open title in January after being deported over his vaccination status.
content: Novak Djokovic, one of the world’s most prominent sports stars to hold out against getting a coronavirus vaccination, was included in the field for this week’s Indian Wells tennis tournament in Southern California, but said Wednesday that he can’t enter the United States and won’t participate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Assassinated in His Prime, an Iconic African Leader Haunts a Trial and His Country
description: Thirty-five years after the killing of President Thomas Sankara of Burkina Faso, his supporters hope for justice. But the full truth about the murder, including any foreign role, is elusive.
content: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Decades later, the scene of the crime is still intact: a deserted building of cracked windowpanes and dust-blown corridors, its courtyard strewn with withered leaves. Gunfire erupted here in October 1987 as Thomas Sankara, the 37-year-old president of Burkina Faso, was meeting with six aides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: When Pigs Cry: Tool Decodes the Emotional Lives of Swine
description: An algorithm built by European researchers could help farmers “speak pig” to improve the animals’ welfare.
content: At any given moment, there are as many as 12,500 Duroc hogs snorting around the barnyards of Imani Farms, a pig farm in southwestern Ontario.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A Bird Is Blamed as 10,000 Lose Power in New Orleans
description: Electricity was restored in the central business district after a three-hour interruption, Entergy New Orleans said.
content: In a city that knows all too well about the fragility of the power grid, it wasn’t a hurricane or a heat wave that knocked out power to thousands of customers in New Orleans on Wednesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: C.E.O.s Are Going Out of Their Way to Punish Russia
description: Companies used to be more wary of political involvement.
content: Companies aren’t just complying with government sanctions imposed on Russia in response to its invasion of Ukraine. In many cases they’re going beyond what’s required. Last Friday, Shell bought 100,000 metric tons of Russian crude oil at a record discount, a fantastic bargain that would ordinarily be cause for celebration at the company. Not with blood being shed in Ukraine, though. On Tuesday, Shell’s chief executive officer, Ben van Beurden, apologized, even though the purchase didn’t violate sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
title: Poland’s Fraught Offer: Fighter Jets for Ukraine, but Only Through U.S. Hands
description: Neither Poland nor the United States wants to make itself — or NATO — a target of Russia. And providing MIG fighters might cross over Putin’s invisible line.
content: President Biden’s commitment to keeping the United States from engaging in direct combat with Russian forces faced an unexpected test this week, when Poland surprised American officials by offering to turn over its collection of aging, Russian-made MIG fighters, for ultimate transfer to Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Changed Itineraries, Higher Fares: How the War in Ukraine Is Affecting Travel
description: How travelers feel the effects of Russia’s assault on Ukraine depends largely on where they’re going, though the price of oil will weigh on all airfares, even domestic.
content: Just as the travel industry was seeking to climb out of a two-year depression, Russia’s assault on Ukraine has scrambled schedules and given Americans pause as they consider international vacations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Englewood, N.J.: A Cosmopolitan Suburb Close to the City
description: The Bergen County city combines an urban vibe with the hilly terrain and residential neighborhoods of a smaller town, just a few miles from Manhattan.
content: With three children under 5, and a fourth on the way, Elizabeth and Alan Mitrani were more than ready to move out of their one-bedroom apartment in New York City, where their living room doubled as a nursery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: California’s Move to Endemicity
description: The state unveiled a “next phase” playbook that will treat the virus as a manageable risk.
content: Last month California became the first state in the U.S. to officially move from a pandemic approach to the virus toward an endemic one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Wildfires in Florida Panhandle Are a ‘Beast,’ Official Says
description: The Chipola Complex, which encompasses three fires, has burned more than 29,000 acres so far. Gov. Ron DeSantis announced over $6 million in relief funds for families affected by the fires.
content: Three sweeping wildfires that started last week in the Florida Panhandle have burned more than 29,000 acres and are threatening surrounding communities amid dry and windy weather, the authorities said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Do Women Need Now?
description: On the final day of the collections, Miu Miu offers attitude and Chanel tweed. But Comme des Garçons presents hope.
content: PARIS — The fall 2022 ready-to-wear shows came to an end on International Women’s Day; a useful reminder, really, of what this is all ultimately about. Even given everything else that is going on. Maybe especially given everything else that is going on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in Virginia, Louisiana and New Jersey
description: A 1912 Greek Revival house in Hopewell, a four-bedroom home near New Orleans and a three-bedroom duplex in Jersey City.
content: This house, known as Miami Lodge, has been owned by the same family for 60 years. Aside from fresh paint and updated structural systems, it has remained virtually unchanged since it was built more than 100 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: A Ukrainian School in New York Takes on a Big Mission
description: As Russia attacks Ukraine, a school’s mission becomes about more than teaching the language; it’s about protecting the culture. “It’s our people, it’s our tradition, it’s our language. It’s our everything.”
content: Today: Ukrainian language schools have become a lifeline for children and parents in the diaspora. And the pandemic has created a national reading crisis, especially among younger children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Real Madrid Rally Leaves P.S.G. Chasing Goals and Ghosts
description: Karim Benzema’s second-half hat trick delivered a familiar disappointment to a star-studded French champion.
content: MADRID — Karim Benzema could not have known, not consciously, what he was doing. It all happened too quickly, too chaotically, to be anything other than instinctual. He was standing on the edge of the Paris St.-Germain box. The ball slipped through a thicket of players. It was at his feet. He jabbed out a foot, a flash of movement, a tic, a twitch. And then everything melted around him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Indiscriminate Attacks in Mariupol
description: Russia was more isolated after sanctions.
content: An apparent Russian strike on a hospital in Mariupol destroyed buildings including a hospital maternity ward, videos verified by The Times show. Here are the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: ‘The Chinese Lady’ Casts a Long Look at Hate
description: Lloyd Suh’s play is a riff on the arrival of the real Afong Moy, possibly the first woman from China in the United States, and a lens on contemporary racism.
content: Afong Moy is known as “The Chinese Lady,” but really she is just a girl — 14 when she arrives alone in New York in 1834, brought by a pair of merchant brothers who struck a deal with her father in China to put her in a museum for two years, on display.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Pithers
title: Cecilie Bahnsen Makes Her Paris Debut
description: Last week, the Danish designer presented a collection just as romantic as the city her namesake brand was showing in for the first time.
content: In a white-walled studio in the Third Arrondissement of Paris two days before Cecilie Bahnsen’s fall 2022 runway presentation, the Danish designer is sitting on the concrete floor pawing a Pop It! toy with a co-worker’s toddler. The casting for the show — her namesake brand’s first in the French capital — is underway, and models are walking up and down the room, narrowly avoiding Bahnsen and the child, who is the daughter of the stylist Emelie Johansson. Then Bahnsen turns her attention to a tall woman with braids who has just entered the room. “Shall we try her in the dress?” she asks her team. They know which one she means: They’ve been working on it all morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Putin Has No Good Way Out, and That Really Scares Me
description: He’s not a man to admit defeat, so he could just keep doubling down.
content: If you’re hoping that the instability that Vladimir Putin’s war on Ukraine has wreaked on global markets and geopolitics has peaked, your hope is in vain. We haven’t seen anything yet. Wait until Putin fully grasps that his only choices left in Ukraine are how to lose — early and small and a little humiliated or late and big and deeply humiliated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Shoalts
title: Alex Ovechkin Skates Into Canada’s Ukrainian Enclave as a Scorned Star
description: The Capitals, led by the Russian president’s high-profile supporter, played the Oilers in Edmonton, home to a large concentration of the Ukrainian diaspora.
content: The hockey star Alex Ovechkin, center among Russian professional athletes in the public’s anger over the war in Ukraine, played before the most unsympathetic crowd yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thessaly La Force
title: Moving Through the Lens
description: After decades of modeling, Guinevere van Seenus, mega-muse of the 1990s, has begun a new chapter in life and love.
content: Like many successful romances, the one between the model and photographer Guinevere van Seenus and the writer and podcaster Beau Friedlander had a middle man: Ms. van Seenus’s three-legged dog, Ashley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Food Companies, Long Symbols of the West in Russia, Pause Operations
description: After years of cultivating the Russian market, McDonald’s, Starbucks, PepsiCo and Coca-Cola said they would temporarily close locations or stop selling products there.
content: When McDonald’s opened its doors in Moscow’s Pushkin Square in 1990, it was welcomed by more than 30,000 Russians who happily waited hours in line, eager to spend a sizable chunk of their daily wages for a taste of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Punk Rock’s New Hope: The Ferocious, Joyful Linda Lindas
description: Fueled by punk conviction (and snacks), this all-girl, school-age band is ready to release its debut album, “Growing Up,” nearly a year after its song “Racist, Sexist Boy” went viral.
content: PIONEERTOWN, Calif. — “Kids to the front!” the drummer shouted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Will Russia’s Isolation Last?
description: Foreign companies and tech powers are increasingly pressured to cut ties over political crises. But then what?
content: Many international businesses in tech and other industries are stopping work in Russia after the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Grace Ashford
title: New Yorkers With Marijuana Convictions Will Get First Retail Licenses
description: Officials intend to reserve the first 100 or more retail licenses to sell marijuana in New York for people who have been convicted of related offenses, or their relatives.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — New York State will soon announce plans to usher in its first outlets for retail sales of marijuana by the end of the year, giving applicants access to stockpiles of the drug grown by local farmers and offering sweeteners like new storefronts leased by the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Republicans, Once Harsh Ukraine Critics, Pivot to Strong Support
description: In a matter of weeks, the center of gravity on Ukraine has sharply shifted among Republicans, muffling doubts about U.S. involvement and dismissing questions about the recent past.
content: WASHINGTON — In the final years of Donald J. Trump’s presidency, Republicans portrayed Ukraine as an Eastern European Wild West run by nefarious oligarchs and unlawful politicians, a bad actor that sought to tamper in American elections and channel millions of dollars to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Loss of Russian Oil Leaves a Void Not Easily Filled, Straining Market
description: Global production will take time to ramp up, so the U.S. and other buyers will chase limited supplies, creating upheaval unseen in decades.
content: HOUSTON — Before its forces invaded Ukraine, Russia provided one out of every 10 barrels of oil the world consumed. But as the United States and other customers shun Russian crude, the global oil market faces its greatest upheaval since the Middle East tumult of the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: The New Phase of the Pandemic Is Covid Exhaustion
description: We’re over Covid. Are we able to move on from it for good?
content: This article is part of Times Opinion’s reflection on the two year mark of the coronavirus pandemic. Read more in a note from Alexandra Sifferlin, Opinion’s health and science editor, in our Opinion Today newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here are some of the businesses that have pledged to cut ties with Russia.
description: Under pressure from investors and consumers, many Western companies have started to unwind their investments, close stores and pause sales in Russia.
content: After the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, ordered the invasion of Ukraine on Feb. 24, multinational companies were forced to re-examine their ties with Russia. Some, like McDonald’s, PepsiCo and Shell, had built relationships with the country over the decades, and were faced with untangling complicated deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu tests positive for the virus.
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the former prime minister of Israel, who is 72 and has gotten four Covid shots, “feels well,” according to a party spokesman.
content: JERUSALEM — Benjamin Netanyahu, the former prime minister of Israel, tested positive for the coronavirus on Wednesday, according to a statement from his conservative Likud party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Empty Stores and an Exodus: Hong Kong’s Covid Crackdown Stirs Panic
description: A surge in cases has alarmed many residents. But the government’s mixed messaging about whether it will impose a lockdown has also been destabilizing.
content: HONG KONG — As the government in Hong Kong struggles to contain the city’s worst Covid outbreak ever, some residents have panicked. They have emptied supermarket shelves of vegetables and meat. They have raided drugstores for pain and fever medication. Those who could afford it have jumped on flights out of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Attack on Turkish Restaurant Lands Two Men in Prison
description: The two California residents, who pleaded guilty to a hate crime, were angry because of Turkey’s support of Azerbaijan in its recent war with Armenia, prosecutors said.
content: Two California men were sentenced this week to federal prison terms for attacking five employees of a Turkish restaurant in Beverly Hills, Calif., in November 2020 because of their anger at Turkey’s support of Azerbaijan in its conflict with Armenia, federal prosecutors said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From the Birth of Hip-Hop to Elena Ferrante
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: ULYSSES, by James Joyce. (Folio, $795.) With illustrations by John Vernon Lord, this extravagant edition of 500 copies celebrates the novel’s 100th anniversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott A. Small
title: We Will Forget Much of the Pandemic. That’s a Good Thing.
description: Remembering too much, too vividly can negatively impact mental health.
content: This article is part of Times Opinion’s reflection on the two-year mark of the Covid pandemic. Read more in a note from Alexandra Sifferlin, Opinion’s health and science editor, in our Opinion Today newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: In Texas, Biden Says New Legislation Could Expand Benefits for Burn Pit Victims
description: The president is focused on veterans who fell ill after breathing in toxic materials from burning waste in Iraq and Afghanistan, exposure that he believes contributed to the death of his elder son.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden called on Tuesday for the broad expansion of health benefits for veterans, particularly those who fell ill after breathing in toxic materials from burning waste in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, exposure that he believes contributed to the cancer that killed his elder son, Beau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe
title: A House panel calls for a criminal investigation into Amazon.
description: Members of the Judiciary Committee accused Amazon of obstructing its inquiry into how the company treats third-party sellers.
content: A House committee asked the Justice Department on Wednesday to investigate Amazon and some of its executives for criminal obstruction of a congressional investigation that included the e-commerce giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon Rags on America’s Gas Problem
description: “Gas prices are so high, the Indy 500 was just changed to the Indy 5,” Fallon joked.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Easterling
title: The Conference Champion Not Going to the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Bellarmine is ineligible for the tournament while the university is in the process from transitioning to Division I from Division II.
content: In college basketball’s midmajor leagues, winning the conference tournament is often the only dependable way for a team to secure an N.C.A.A. tournament bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: They Died by a Bridge in Ukraine. This Is Their Story.
description: Tetiana Perebyinis and her two children were killed trying to dash to safety, a moment captured by our photographer. Her husband describes their lives, and their final hours.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — They met in high school but became a couple years later, after meeting again on a dance floor at a Ukrainian nightclub. Married in 2001, they lived in a bedroom community outside Kyiv, in an apartment with their two children and their dogs, Benz and Cake. She was an accountant and he was a computer programmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Much of Smartmatic Case Against Fox News Can Proceed, Judge Rules
description: The judge did dismiss some defamation claims, against Rudolph W. Giuliani, Jeanine Pirro and Sidney Powell.
content: The $2.7 billion defamation lawsuit against Fox News by the election technology company Smartmatic can move forward, a New York judge ruled on Tuesday. But the judge tossed out Smartmatic’s defamation claims against the Fox News host Jeanine Pirro and a network guest, Sidney Powell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A New Iron Curtain Is Falling
description: The isolation of the Russian economy is striking in its speed and scope.
content: Each day brings more economic punishments for Russia after its invasion of Ukraine. The sudden isolation of the Russian economy is striking in its speed and scope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How the War in Ukraine Hurt a Gas Station Owner on Long Island
description: Ganesh Lall is Guyanese, but customers are shunning his station because of its Russian name.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at gasoline stations in the New York area that are under pressure because of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. We’ll also find out about a tree in Miami Beach with a guardian in SoHo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Sex-Trafficking Couple Exploited Foster Care Loophole, Officials Say
description: A Bronx couple used foster care to exploit vulnerable young women, prosecutors and a woman who had been placed in their home said.
content: When Sharice Mitchell became a foster parent early in 2019, she told the officials responsible for vetting her that she was separated from her husband and had not been in contact with him for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger, Aatish Bhatia and Quoctrung Bui
title: Bacon, Gas and Essentials: Where 2,200 Americans Have Noticed Inflation
description: Nearly nine in 10 Americans say they have noticed prices rising around them. And, when asked which of the price increases have caught their attention, many mentioned basic necessities.
content: Nearly nine in 10 Americans say they have noticed prices rising around them. And, when asked which of the price increases have caught their attention, many mentioned basic necessities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Sell My Soul and Hopefully Start Over With a New One.’
description: The novelist Sheila Heti puts her diary in alphabetical order to see if she’s changed over the years.
content: The novelist Sheila Heti puts her diary in alphabetical order to see if she’s changed over the years.

title: How Well Do You Know ‘The Godfather’? The Quiz Nobody Asked For
description: Accept this quiz as a gift for the film’s 50th anniversary.

description: A 1912 Greek Revival house in Hopewell, Va.; a four-bedroom home near New Orleans; and a three-bedroom duplex in Jersey City, N.J.
content: A 1912 Greek Revival house in Hopewell, Va.; a four-bedroom home near New Orleans; and a three-bedroom duplex in Jersey City, N.J.

description: The Bergen County city combines an urban vibe with the hilly terrain and residential neighborhoods of a smaller town, just a few miles from Manhattan.

title: A Perch Over the Caribbean Sea on Tortola Island
description: This four-bedroom hillside property with Atlantic Ocean views on the coast of Tortola, in the British Virgin Islands, is for sale for $1.85 million.

author: By Emily Rhyne, Simon Ostrovsky and Ben Laffin
title: ‘I Must Save My Mom’: The Women Returning to Ukraine
description: As millions seek to escape Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, 200,000 people have gone the other way, toward the fighting. Many are women, risking the dangers of war to rescue relatives or defend their homes.
content: As millions seek to escape Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, 200,000 people have gone the other way, toward the fighting. Many are women, risking the dangers of war to rescue relatives or defend their homes.

author: By Chevaz Clarke-Williams and Rex Sakamoto
title: Australia Declares National Emergency Amid Severe Flooding
description: Scott Morrison, the prime minister of Australia, said the deadly downpours that forced thousands of people to evacuate the nation’s eastern coast are making the country harder to live in.
content: Scott Morrison, the prime minister of Australia, said the deadly downpours that forced thousands of people to evacuate the nation’s eastern coast are making the country harder to live in.

title: Fiction With a Covid Theme: Will It Sell?
description: Two writers and a social worker discuss the challenges of writing books about the pandemic. Also: Photojournalists’ bravery; Ukraine’s lithium; crosswalk danger.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Prepping for St. Patrick’s Day
description: Corn some beef for Irish tacos.
content: Good morning. It’s a project to be sure, but maybe you should take the approaching St. Patrick’s Day holiday on March 17 as a chance to corn your own beef, and then to use the meat in whatever way pleases you most: for corned beef and cabbage, say, or Irish tacos (above). The process yields incredible flavor, far beyond anything you can get out of the briskets in that tub at the grocery store, and it’s deeply rewarding to boot. Get started as soon as you can.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 9, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 9, 2022.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about internet blockages in Russia misspelled the surname of an Oxford University researcher. He is Aliaksandr Herasimenka, not Herasmenka.
source.name: The New York Times
